proof: Proof. If $t = m$, then $v$ cannot be dead at time $t$. Otherwise, since $1 \le t \le m-1$, $t$ is the midpoint of some subproblem $[l, r]$ with $r-l \ge 2$, which means $l < t$. If $v$ is dead at time $t$, then $\tilde{d}^l(v) = \tilde{d}^t(v)$. If $l = t-1$, the claim is proven. Otherwise, we must have $t-1 \in (l, t)$. Since $v$ is dead over the interval $[l, t]$, its distance estimate must be constant. Therefore, for any two points in this interval, including $t-1$ and $t$, the distance estimates must be equal, so $\tilde{d}^{t-1}(v) = \tilde{d}^t(v)$.
